talks.title: A small leak can sink a great ship
talks.abstract:
Memory plays an important role in making an Android application famous. The application will run faster on the Android ecosystem with less memory requirement.
Android ecosystem tries to keep as many applications in memory as possible to enable quicker & smoother switching between applications and tasks, keeping a device feeling ‚Äúsnappy‚Äù to the end user.
So, the lesser the memory requirement, the faster the app will run on a device.

So to enhance the user experience and to strengthen the Android ecosystem, memory pressure will be directly proportional to app stability, thus bringing memory leaks into the picture.

High memory leaks lead to sluggy apps or skipping frames during its execution or even termination of your application in the middle of critical work. And finally, you may end up with a crash report that doesn't appear to be memory related.

Most developers do not focus on memory leaks till they are noticeable due to ANR / Out of memory errors, at which point they require a significant rewrite. During development and testing, using tools such as LeakCanary can help you detect and resolve memory leaks.

But now it's time to explore LeakCanary 2 & Integration with a dashboard like Firebase to analyze memory pitfalls for apps. Just a simplified way to detect memory leaks during development and testing automation.
How to prioritize bugs by collecting all memory leaks in a dashboard (Not all bugs are worth fixing. Only fix the ones that matter.

So let's fix the leak in this great ship to sail high !!

talks.title: Exploiting AWS Misconfigurations: A Capture the Flag Workshop
talks.abstract:
Are you ready to become a hacker and try to exploit vulnerabilities in the Cloud?
Then join us for our exciting Capture the Flag workshop where you‚Äôll learn about the dangers of AWS environments configurations pitfalls and how to exploit them.

This workshop will cover the following topics: S3, EC2 instance, Lambda code injection, IAM privesc, Policy rollback, ...

By the end of this workshop, you will have a better understanding of the potential misconfigurations impact on your own AWS infrastructures and the steps you can take to secure them.

## Prerequisite
As we cannot cover for the expense of multiple AWS environments, this workshop requires you to have a working AWS account with admin privileges and have Terraform installed on your laptop.
We will provide you a Terraform script to deploy a vulnerable by design AWS environment, but fear not, it will only be accessible by your IP, and will be destroyed at the end of the workshop.
talks.references:
# Exploiting AWS Misconfigurations: A Capture the Flag Workshop
This workshop is based on the Capture the Flag format, which will provide attendees with a fun and engaging way to learn about AWS misconfigurations and how to exploit them. The goal is to raise awareness on the importance of secure configuration and the potential consequences of _small_ mistakes.

## Description 
Participants will gain a deeper understanding of the risks associated with using AWS Cloud services, and learn how attackers exploit misconfigurations to gain access to cloud environments. As teams, (it's less fun but workshop can also be done alone) they will try to identify and exploit vulnerabilities a simulated AWS environment.
We will provide a Terraform script to deploy a vulnerable by design AWS environment (only accessible by the attendee IP) and a step-by-step instructions and guidance to identify and exploit common configuration pitfall in the AWS platform. We will also provide help and answer questions during the workshop.
  
By the end of this workshop, participants will have a better understanding of the potential misconfigurations impact in their own AWS infrastructures and the steps they can take to secure them.

The following topics will be covered : S3 bad configuration, EC2 instance bad configuration, Lambda code injection, IAM  privesc, Policy rollback

## Prerequisite
As we cannot cover for the expense of multiple AWS environments, this workshop requires attendees to have a working AWS account with admin privileges and have Terraform installed. 

## About ourselves
We (Jean and myself) lead a workshop about JWT common mistakes, and how an attacker can leverage them, in multiple conferences: Devoxx Fr, DevFest Nantes, Very Tech Trip.

Appart from this I also speaked at DevFest Strasbourg, Toulouse Hacking Conference, and Capitole du Libre.

With this workshop we want to raise awareness about Cloud Security and help people to understand the basics of a secure Cloud infrastructure.

talks.title: Hydration, Islands, Streaming, Resumability‚Ä¶ Oh¬†My!
talks.abstract:
Our ecosystem can be overwhelming! First, we had the rise of SSR and SSG‚Äîand each had its¬†own¬†gigantic pile of frameworks and tools. Then partial hydration enabled us to hydrate only some of our components on the client, which we've seen in React Server Components. 

But what about islands? Do they relate at all to Streaming SSR? Moreover, what is resumability, and why do I keep hearing about it? [‚Ä¶] Oh, did anyone say rendering on the Edge?

Well‚Ä¶ There are many approaches out there, and all of them argue that their philosophy is best. In this session, we‚Äôll go over these architecture/rendering patterns, to help shed some light on how some are implemented and the concepts behind them.

talks.title: La compression Web : comment (re)prendre le contr√¥le ?
talks.abstract:
Saviez-vous que toute la journ√©e, nos serveurs compressent nos r√©ponses HTTP et que nos navigateurs les d√©compressent ? C'est comme si on passait notre temps √† plier des T-shirts et √† les d√©plier. Cette compression est partout sur le Web, et pourtant ses subtilit√©s nous √©chappent souvent. On compresse des formats qui n'en ont pas besoin, on compresse √† la vol√©e des fichiers statiques, on n'adopte pas les nouveaux algorithmes... Bref, on remplit les tuyaux d'internet plus que n√©cessaire, comme si on remplissait notre valise de chaussettes en boule.

Mais rassurez-vous, il y a de l'espoir ! Dans cette session, nous allons (re)d√©couvrir la compression pour le Web. Nous vous pr√©senterons les principaux algorithmes de compression comme gzip et brotli, ainsi que les techniques sous-jacentes. Nous aborderons √©galement la n√©gociation de contenu entre les serveurs et les navigateurs.

Enfin, nous partagerons avec vous des bonnes pratiques √† adopter pour √©viter les mauvaises surprises : des exemples concrets, des mesures et quelques astuces pour am√©liorer les performances de votre site web. Car, oui, optimiser la compression de vos donn√©es, c'est un peu comme optimiser votre valise avant de partir en vacances : vous gagnez de la place, vous √™tes plus efficace, et vous √©vitez de criser sur cette satan√©e fermeture √©clair qui ne veut pas se fermer !
talks.comments:
Il s'agit d'une proposition toute neuve qui n'a jamais √©t√© pr√©sent√©e.
C'est un sujet qu'on creuse tous les deux √† notre mani√®re depuis plusieurs mois et qui nous int√©resse beaucoup.
Nous voulons faire une pr√©sentation avec des slides interactifs, des d√©mos et des exemples concrets.

Une personne qui a suivi la pr√©sentation repart avec :

* une connaissance des algos, des variantes etc...
* une compr√©hension de TCP/IP/HTTP (li√© √† l'usage de la compression)
* une vision claire de la n√©cessit√© de la compression dans le Web
* des bonnes pratiques
* des alertes sur les mauvaises pratiques

Cette pr√©sentation s'adresse donc √† des devs frontend, backend, novice pour de la d√©couverte ou expert pour certains rappels.

talks.title: Feature Flags with OpenFeature: Enabling Faster, More Collaborative Development
talks.abstract:
Feature flags and open source software are both powerful tools for managing and controlling software features and functionality. With feature flags, developers can deploy new code changes without immediately exposing them to all users, enabling faster and more controlled release cycles. OpenFeature, an open source project for feature development and testing, enables teams to collaborate on feature development and testing in real-time.

In this talk, we will explore the benefits of using feature flags and OpenFeature in software development, as well as strategies for successful implementation and use. We'll discuss how to set up feature flags and OpenFeature in your codebase, how to manage them over time, and how to use them to support continuous delivery and experimentation.

We'll also cover best practices for using feature flags and OpenFeature, including how to collaborate effectively with cross-functional teams, how to measure the impact of different feature flag strategies on user engagement and adoption, and how to integrate OpenFeature with your existing feature flagging practices.

By the end of this talk, you'll have a solid understanding of the benefits of feature flags with OpenFeature, as well as practical strategies for using them effectively in your software development process. Whether you're a developer, manager, or technical leader, you'll walk away with actionable insights and best practices to help you streamline your release cycle, improve your overall software quality, and foster more collaborative and innovative development practices within your team.
talks.references: https://openfeature.dev

En ce qui concerne les smart-contracts, la structure g√©n√©rale sera √©galement fournie, de sorte que les participants se concentrent sur l'impl√©mentation des √©l√©ments li√©s aux besoins fonctionnels du lab, tels que la gestion de la nomination des films, des membres du jury, du vote par le jury et de la remise des prix pour les films du festival du cin√©ma du DevFest.

talks.comments:

Et la fameuse question: est-ce que la passion fait d'une personne un(e) meilleur(e) d√©veloppeur(euse) ?

Cette question oppose g√©n√©ralement deux √©coles. La premi√®re part du principe que la passion est indispensable pour avoir une carri√®re de dev r√©ussie.
La seconde en revanche estime que le m√©tier de d√©veloppeur peut s'exercer 

Les profils de reconversion sont de plus en plus nombreux dans le d√©veloppement web. Alors, je veux √† travers ce talk montrer qu‚Äôil est non seulement possible de n‚Äôavoir jamais cod√© et de se reconvertir mais aussi qu‚Äôil est accessible √† tous de mieux comprendre ces profils et donc mieux les int√©grer dans le paysage du d√©veloppement web. 

D'abord, nous parlerons de ce qu'est la passion dans tous ses √©tats (dans la vie personnelle comme professionnelle) et ses m√©caniques psychologiques. Puis, nous analyserons les deux √©coles pro/contre passion pour pouvoir, ensemble, parvenir √† un compromis, une tentative de r√©ponse √† cette question sous-jacente "Si tu n'es pas passionn√©, tu ne seras pas un bon dev ?" !

talks.title: Du CSS aux shaders WebGL : panorama des techniques d'animation en 2023
talks.abstract:
Parfois subtiles, parfois pro√©minentes, les animations sont un √©l√©ment essentiel pour une exp√©rience utilisateur agr√©able. Mais une fois qu'on a imagin√© des animations plus ou moins folles, vient la question fatidique du "comment fait-on √ßa ?", √† laquelle j'aimerais vous aider √† r√©pondre.

Pour pouvoir choisir la technique la mieux adapt√©e √† chaque animation, il vaut mieux avoir une bo√Æte √† outils la plus compl√®te possible. J'aimerais vous aider √† construire la v√¥tre en vous pr√©sentant un panel le plus large possible de techniques d'animation sur le web : des APIs natives classiques (CSS, Web Animation API) aux plus complexes (Canvas API) en passant par les librairies sp√©cialis√©es (FLIP, Lottie, Framer Motion, Rive...). Nous finirons avec WebGL et ses shaders GLSL, qui feraient trembler plus d'un d√©veloppeur mais dont on retrouve les effets impressionnants sur tous les sites r√©compens√©s aux Awwwards.

Je passerai rapidement sur toutes ces techniques, en comparant leurs performances et utilisations possibles, afin de vous laisser la libert√© d'explorer plus en profondeur celles qui vous int√©ressent.
talks.references:
## Slides
https://jsulpis.github.io/talk-animation-techniques/#/

## Sommaire

1. **introduction** : pourquoi faire des animations, DOM & canvas, CPU & GPU...
2. **les APIs natives** : transitions & animations CSS, Web Animation API, requestAnimationFrame
3. **les librairies JS** : frameworks (Vue, React, Svelte, Angular), librairies (Framer Motion, @vueuse/motion, gsap, anime.js, Motion One, Lottie)
4. **canvas 2D** : API canvas, librairies
5. **canvas WebGL** : API webGL, three.js, shaders glsl (fragment & vertex)
6. **conclusion** : r√©cap, accessibilit√©, inspiration

Pour chaque technique j'explique rapidement comment elle fonctionne, ses performances (si elle utilise le CPU ou le GPU), et dans quels cas l'utiliser, toujours avec des exemples.
Je vulgarise les parties plus techniques pour que le talk reste accessible au plus grand nombre.

talks.title: WebAssembly beyond the browser
talks.abstract:
WebAssembly (Wasm) allows you to compile code written in over 40 programming languages and run it in a secure and performant way in web browsers. The WebAssembly System Interface (WASI) has expanded the capabilities of Wasm by enabling it to run outside the web browser, such as server-side applications, edge computing, and cloud microservices. Docker has also recently announced support for Wasm, allowing it to be used as a lightweight alternative to Linux and Windows containers.

Whether Wasm will replace containers remains to be seen but it‚Äôs definitely worth learning more about it. In this talk, I‚Äôll introduce Wasm, the basic terminology around it, and its current state as a server side technology. We will also look at some examples and tools for working with Wasm on the server side.

talks.title: We‚Äôre Not doing Design Systems Properly and That‚Äôs Okay
talks.abstract:
How do you ‚Äòdo‚Äô Design Systems? Expectations are so high nowadays. Implement Design Tokens. Have a dedicated Design System team. Get a Design System manager. Wait, does your Design System even have a name?

There isn‚Äôt one way to do Design Systems. Ours ticks none of these boxes, yet today, it allows us to build from the simplest to the most complex financial tools, and design systematically across our services. In this session, we‚Äôll share the lessons we learned on prioritising impacts over grip.

Takeaways:
- Understand that there‚Äôs no one way to do Design Systems
- How to adapt for adoption
- How to use the Design System mindset for large-scale pattern-based thinking

talks.title: The laundromat : quand les journalistes deviennent data analystes

talks.title: Et si l'IA √©tait la solution pour comprendre la langue des signes ?
talks.abstract:
Dans le domaine de l'Intelligence Artificielle, nous parlons souvent de Computer Vision et d'Object Detection, mais au final que signifient ces termes et surtout comment peuvent-ils nous aider dans la vie courante ?

Durant ce talk nous allons tout d'abord tenter de comprendre la place qu'occupe l'IA dans le vaste domaine de la sant√©. Nous montrerons ensuite l'importance de la donn√©e et nous d√©velopperons une app capable de d√©tecter et d'interpr√©ter la langue des signes.

Ce talk montrera comment il est possible de traiter la donn√©e avec du traitement d'image pour enrichir ses donn√©es d'entra√Ænement.

La seconde √©tape consistera √† entra√Æner un mod√®le de d√©tection d'objets √† reconna√Ætre les diff√©rents signes de l'alphabet ASL (American Sign Language) au travers d'un notebook Jupyter. .

Une fois le  mod√®le construit et entrain√© quoi de mieux que de cr√©er ensemble une application ? Cette derni√®re sera bas√©e sur les technologiques Cloud et container et nous verrons comment cr√©er et d√©ployer un tel outil.

talks.comments:
Bonjour !

Tout d'abord merci pour l'organisation de ce DevFest Nantes 2023 !

L'objectif de ce talk est de montrer qu'il est possible de cr√©er et de d√©ployer un mod√®le d'intelligence artificielle facilement pour la reconnaissance de la langue des signes.

Le but est d'embarquer un maximum de personnes dans cette aventure, qu'elles soient issues du monde "Data & IA" ou non. Par cons√©quent, la cr√©ation et le d√©ploiement d'un tel mod√®le se fera pas √† pas.

Pour ce faire, je me baserai sur un Notebook Jupyter pour aborder la phase traitement de donn√©es mais √©galement l'entra√Ænement du mod√®le d'IA. 
Je partirai d'un mod√®le existant permettant la d√©tection d'objets sur une image ou un flux vid√©o. Le mod√®le en question se nomme YOLOv7 et est particuli√®rement connu pour sa rapidit√© et sa pr√©cision. L'objectif sera donc de montrer son entra√Ænement dans le Notebook Jupyter de mani√®re ludique.

talks.title: Navigating the Chaos: A Holistic Approach to Incident Management
talks.abstract:
Incident management can be challenging and throw you curveballs with unexpected issues, resulting in data loss, downtimes, and overall money & hours of sleep going to waste, BUT! There are practical things you could do to make it a smoother process and handle it better.

Remember when we were at school, and people said - "Actively listening in class guarantees 50% prep for the upcoming test"?
The same goes for being proactive at work in ways that will instantly prepare you to manage incidents better (at night or in general).

In this talk, I'll cover the proactive ways you could take and incorporate into your day-to-day routine, in order to prepare you for a smoother and more efficient incident management process.

I will also show the best practices I've finalized over the years that helped me get a clear vision of how to manage production incidents in the quickest & efficient way possible.
Embracing the tips I'll give you will guarantee you'll not only talk the talk but also walk the walk when it comes to incident management.
talks.references:
You can watch the talk here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_weSBYwf_m0


Outline:
I will start by giving a short pitch of why they should listen to me, a.k.a wiifm about this talk.
then a short intro about myself.
and then start the actual talk by going over what incident management is.
The needed mindset for it, and if needed - I encourage the audience to reframe their perspective about it - to a business mindset.
then I outlay the pillars of the incident management structured process and which questions they should ask themselves during an incident in order to manage it efficiently and reach faster MTTR.
I'll touch a little bit about 'war room' conduct.
outlay the necessary qualities for an incident manager/on-call person.
and then explain how we can do better -
the proactive approach after the fact, a.k.a after an incident took place - things they should do to prepare the land for the next incident to be handled better and smoother.
and also the proactive approach needed (in my opinion) on our day-to-day, things we can do daily or have as second nature, that will help us come prepared for an incident and manage it better.

Key takeaways:
I‚Äôll cover 3 aspects to handle incidents better ‚Äì a structured process to follow upon any incident to cover all grounds & having business interest in mind & heart, needed characteristics with tips on how to strengthen them and proactive approach towards incidents management ‚Äì things to do in your day-to-day and after the fact (after an incident took place) to be prepared for any incident that will come and make the incident management process more efficient.

talks.title: L'AGC : retour sur l'ordinateur qui a amen√© l'humanit√© sur la Lune
talks.abstract:
Lundi 21 juillet 1969, l‚Äôhumanit√© posait pour la premi√®re fois le pied sur la Lune. Cet exploit est le fruit de nombreuses avanc√©es techniques et technologiques, notamment en √©lectronique et dans le domaine de l‚Äôinformatique alors naissant. Pour mener √† bien leurs missions, les astronautes s‚Äôappuyaient sur l‚ÄôAGC, l‚Äôordinateur de bord du programme Apollo qui permettra de r√©aliser ces exploits. 

Embarquez avec nous et d√©couvrons ensemble sa conception et les r√¥les qu‚Äôil devait assurer au cours d‚Äôune mission jusqu‚Äô√† la Lune. Nous nous replacerons dans le contexte historique, aborderons les moyens qui √©taient alors √† disposition des ing√©nieurs de l‚Äô√©poque, les avanc√©es technologiques qui ont √©t√© n√©cessaires pour relever ce d√©fi ainsi que les h√©ritages que ce programme nous aura laiss√©, notamment dans le domaine de l'ing√©nierie logicielle.

talks.title: Go Serverless! But is it secure?
talks.abstract:
I am a big advocate of serverless products instead of "traditional" ones. Cloud Run instead of GKE, Fargate instead of EKS, Pub/Sub instead of Kafka and Aurora instead of RDS. You get lower costs, less infra to manage, no need to worry about networking... But what about security? Can you really make sure that your serverless workloads (or data) are safe? 

In this talk, we will go through several serverless offerings in the areas of data & compute, and look at their vulnerabilities and security options. We'll cover topics like:

- How serverless architecture changes the attack surface
- Vulnerabilities in serverless platforms and services
- Best practices for securing serverless workloads

By the end of this talk, you'll be able to:

- Understand the security risks of serverless computing
- Implement best practices for securing your serverless workloads
- Sleep soundly knowing that your serverless applications are secure
talks.comments: Ce talk est possible dans les 2 formats - Conference et Quickie, ainsi qu'en Fran√ßais.
talks.references: I've given several talks about securing data platforms in the cloud (for example, here https://datateamssummit.com/2022-2/multi-cloud-tight-regulations/ and here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P1bTBwlyPtU), and have also written blogs directly or indirectly related to serverless security (example https://medium.com/google-cloud/the-misadventures-of-one-cloud-function-edd8e4036e92)

talks.title: Workshop sur l'Int√©gration √† l'√®re du cloud avec Camel Quarkus
talks.abstract:
Dans un univers informatique dont l'expansion ne cesse d'acc√©l√©rer, le besoin de faire communiquer des syst√®mes disparates se renforce jour apr√®s jour.
D√©velopp√© en Java, le projet Open Source [Apache Camel](https://camel.apache.org/) fournit avec ses 350 connecteurs une r√©ponse prouv√©e √† ce besoin toujours croissant d'int√©gration entre syst√®mes.

Mais √† l'√®re du cloud, des projets comme [Quarkus](https://quarkus.io/) change compl√®tement la donne. Simplicit√© de d√©veloppement, d√©marrage d'une JVM en quelques milli-secondes, faible consommation m√©moire... Comment Camel peut-il profiter de ces nouveaux avantages ? C'est tout l'objet du projet [Camel Quarkus](https://camel.apache.org/camel-quarkus/latest/) que nous aimerions faire d√©couvrir lors de cette pr√©sentation.

Dans ce workshop, nous souhaitons aborder certaines notions importantes de Quarkus et Camel:
+ Le DEV mode de Quarkus
+ Le mode JVM de Quarkus
+ Les routes de Camel Quarkus
+ Les composants de Camel Quarkus
+ Les Enterprise Integration Pattern de Camel Quarkus

talks.title: Unlocking the power of Web Machine Learning: Hands-on TensorFlow.js workshop

Cordialement,

Voici la structure que j'imagine pour ce talk:

3. Solution : Comment optimiser les co√ªts dans le Cloud :

talks.title: Expand your view of your application performance with OpenTelemetry
talks.abstract:
**FRENCH TALK**

OpenTelemetry is a powerful open-source **observability framework** that provides a unified way to collect, process, and export telemetry data from distributed systems. In this talk, we will explore the capabilities of OpenTelemetry and demonstrate how it can be used to gain deep insights into the performance and behavior of complex applications.

During the **live demonstration**, we will showcase how OpenTelemetry can be used to instrument a sample application and collect metrics, traces, and logs. We will explore the different components of OpenTelemetry, including the SDKs, the collector, and the exporters, and demonstrate how they work together to provide a comprehensive view of application performance.

We will also showcase how OpenTelemetry can be integrated with other observability tools, such as **Jaeger**, **Prometheus**, **Uptrace** and **Elastic APM**.

Throughout the talk, we will provide tips and best practices for using OpenTelemetry effectively, including how to choose the right instrumentation and how to configure the collector and exporters for optimal performance.

By the end of this talk, attendees will have a deep understanding of the capabilities of OpenTelemetry and how it can be used to gain insights into complex applications. They will also be equipped with the knowledge necessary to start using OpenTelemetry in their own applications and take advantage of its powerful observability capabilities.
talks.references:
- No slides yet :)
- I'm using OpenTelemetry @ Decathlon for some months and I found this piece of technology amazing
- Talk will contains a large live demonstration of OpenTelemetry integrated with various "visualisation tools" (Jaeger, Uptrace, Elastic APM...)

talks.title: Les meilleurs outils de dev sont-il dans le Cloud?

Si le probl√®me du "Works on my machine" a √©t√© r√©gl√© par Docker, alors pourquoi passe-t-on encore plusieurs heures et parfois plusieurs jours √† configurer son poste de d√©veloppement?

talks.title: Alfredo Linguini et les Mod√®les G√©n√©ratifs : Qui Fait Vraiment la Cuisine ?

Comme Alfredo Linguini dans le film Ratatouille, qui a su cr√©er des plats d√©licieux en confiant le contr√¥le de sa cuisine √† un rat dou√© nomm√© R√©my, nous examinons comment les mod√®les de langue g√©n√©ratifs agissent comme notre "R√©my" personnel, aidant √† concocter du contenu de qualit√©.

Ensuite, nous explorerons l'art du "Prompt Design" avec un accent particulier sur la fiabilit√©. Nous discuterons des strat√©gies pour am√©liorer les r√©ponses des mod√®les, et aborderons les mesures de s√©curit√© n√©cessaires pour assurer que notre "cuisine" IA reste s√ªre et fiable.

Tel un plat signature de Gusteau's, nous pr√©senterons une d√©monstration sur un cas d'usage concret impl√©ment√© en entreprise. Cette d√©mo donnera un aper√ßu de la mani√®re dont les IA g√©n√©ratives peuvent √™tre d√©ploy√©es dans le monde r√©el et cr√©er de la valeur pour les organisations.

Enfin, nous vous pr√©parerons votre doggy bag : des astuces pour les d√©veloppeurs, des r√©flexions sur les √©checs et les succ√®s dans l'adoption de ces technologies, une discussion sur la strat√©gie Make or Buy et un √©clairage sur l'approche open source. Nous partagerons des anecdotes, des le√ßons apprises et des conseils pour naviguer dans le monde de l'IA g√©n√©rative.

Rejoignez-nous pour cette aventure culinaire dans le monde des IA g√©n√©ratives et d√©couvrons ensemble "qui fait vraiment la cuisine" dans le monde technologique d'aujourd'hui

talks.title: Towards a 'carbon-aware' cloud.
talks.abstract:
The cloud holds a dirty secret: it generates as much greenhouse gas emissions as entire countries like France or the United Kingdom ([IEA, 2021](https://www.iea.org/reports/data-centres-and-data-transmission-networks)). But there is hope! Infra & Cloud teams have the power to mitigate this issue. By simply choosing the right cloud region on platforms like GCP, Azure, or AWS, emissions can be reduced by a factor of 10 or even 20.

In this talk, we will explore the regulatory landscape and financial incentives driving organizations to tackle their cloud's carbon footprint. I will show practical techniques to measure and estimate emissions using observability tools, with live data. Then, I will talk about concrete strategies to minimize your infrastructure's carbon impact.

I will introduce the concept of a "carbon-aware" infrastructure that dynamically self-adjusts according to its own emission levels. Explore how to intelligently schedule resource-intensive tasks, targeting regions with low-carbon intensity or delaying them until better weather conditions. Eventually, I will show how we can shrink or move an infrastructure where electricity is "greener," automatically.

By transforming your cloud into a carbon-aware infrastructure, you can make a huge environmental impact while keeping good performance.

talks.title: The Ethics of Generative AI
talks.abstract: In a brave new world filled with unattributed text, filtered images, remixed sounds, and bot-generated refurbished art, where do we find ourselves? Can we merrily maneuver through ChatGPT to generate all the written text we ever need, park on the Midjourney Discord server to gather all the art we might ever want to look at, and listen to endlessly sampled sounds that melt away into the void? How are we to find our moral bearings in a morass of an ai-generated reality? In this talk, I‚Äôll walk through a framework around understanding various aspects of the ethics of moral philosophy, and then working backwards to understand where generative AI fits into this framework and whether we can find acceptable use cases for it.
talks.comments: thanks, friends!
talks.references: In 2019, I gave a keynote at ImageCon in San Francisco about the Ethics of Imagery. While many of the points I made in this talk still hold true regarding the use of imagery in memes, stock photos, art, and more, I would like to update my thoughts on this topic to encompass the concept of how we can ethically use generative AI tooling. Using the same framework to discuss ethics, I'd like to work backwards and talk about the core problem of generative AI, the use and misuse of proprietary ideas, text, images, and artworks, potentially under restrictive license or copyrighted, and how to give attribution in a world where sources melt away into algorithms. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4Zhjy3Mdtbc&t=1s&ab_channel=Cloudinary

talks.title: Comment hacker vos applications mobiles ?
talks.abstract:
Nous utilisons tous des applications mobiles pour payer, s'authentifier ou consulter nos comptes bancaires. Etant donn√© la sensibilit√© de ces actions, nous faisons confiance aux √©diteurs que sont les banques ou le service publique. Mais peut-on hacker de telles applications ou les donn√©es qu'elles contiennent ?  Yes, we can !
Quels sont ces moyens d'attaque ? Quels sont les risques et que pouvons-nous faire pour les r√©duire ?

La s√©curit√© mobile est au c≈ìur du m√©tier de notre √©quipe car nous travaillons quotidiennement √† prot√©ger les applications mobiles de nos clients. Dans cette pr√©sentation nous nous focaliserons sur le pentest (la partie offensive de notre activit√©) en alliant explications et d√©monstrations.
Cette conf√©rence s‚Äôadresse donc √† un public technique assez large : des personnes int√©ress√©es par la s√©curit√© des applications mobiles, que ce soit simplement pour se rendre compte des attaques possibles ou bien pour les mettre en pratique.

Nous allons utiliser un t√©l√©phone root√©, pour analyser une application Android et la modifier gr√¢ce au reverse engineering. Ensuite, nous approfondirons l‚Äôanalyse avec l'utilisation d'outils permettant de modifier dynamiquement le comportement de l'application lors de son ex√©cution. Enfin nous √©voquerons les protections √† mettre en place pour √©viter ces attaques.

A l'issu de notre pr√©sentation, vous aurez une meilleure vision du pentest mobile et les bases n√©cessaires pour utiliser les outils √©l√©mentaires de ce domaine.

talks.title: Rendu 3D, la grande illusion expliqu√©e
talks.abstract:
Dans les jeux vid√©o, le cin√©ma, l‚Äôindustrie, la m√©decine ou encore l‚Äôurbanisme, la 3D est partout. Nous l‚Äôutilisons aujourd‚Äôhui pour nous divertir, apprendre, simuler les prochaines  catastrophes ou encore le fonctionnement de la voiture du futur. Demain, nous l‚Äôutiliserons pour explorer de nouvelles fa√ßons de communiquer, de construire et de cr√©er. 

Mais comment fonctionne ce rendu 3D qui donne vie √† ces univers virtuels ? Quel lien y-a-t- il entre notre vision et notre carte graphique ? Sur un √©cran, qui n‚Äôest qu‚Äôune grille de pixels, la 3D existe-t-elle vraiment ? 

Pour r√©pondre √† ces questions, nous allons voir les diff√©rentes √©tapes n√©cessaires qu‚Äôun ordinateur doit accomplir pour tromper notre cerveau. Gr√¢ce √† une explication pas √† pas, nous pourrons comprendre le fonctionnement de cette grande illusion.
talks.comments: I hope to see you soon and thank you for the organisation
talks.references:
Dans les jeux vid√©o, le cin√©ma, la m√©decine, l‚Äôindustrie ou encore l‚Äôurbanisme, la 3D est partout. Apr√®s avoir pass√© 3 ans dans ce domaine chez Dassault Syst√®mes et en discutant avec des personnes autour de moi, j‚Äôai r√©alis√© que la 3D √©tait souvent per√ßue comme quelque chose de magique. Elle est comme une illusion ne pouvant pas √™tre expliqu√©e mais pouvant donner vie √† des univers virtuels. C‚Äôest pour construire un pont nous emmenant de l‚Äôautre c√¥t√© des apparences que cette conf√©rence est pr√©vue.

Apr√®s avoir bri√®vement retrac√© le fonctionnement de la cr√©ation d‚Äôun monde 3D avec nos outils modernes, je partirais de cette cr√©ation pour expliquer comment les objets qui la composent sont localis√©s √† l'√©cran. Je pr√©senterais les primitives qui composent ces objets ainsi que diff√©rentes projections n√©cessaires pour les aplatir sur un √©cran.
Une seconde partie sera d√©di√©e √† la mani√®re dont les pixels se colorisent pour r√©aliser l‚Äôimage 3D attendue. Nous d√©couvrirons le r√¥le des shaders, de la lumi√®re et des mat√©riaux dans ce proc√©d√© de colorisation.

Mon but est de donner un aper√ßu du fonctionnement des rendus 3D, introduction permettant d'appr√©cier davantage les subtilit√©s de ces derniers.

Ce talk a √©t√© donn√© au format 15 minutes au [DevoxxFR 2022](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0vF2G6vRB7M&ab_channel=DevoxxFR) ainsi qu'√† [Touraine Tech 2023](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u-DHkiU6p4Q&ab_channel=TouraineTech)

talks.title: Towards Modern Development of Cloud Applications
talks.comments:
We can also organize a Service Weaver workshop if that's possible. 

We are going on a Service Weaver tour, trying to educate people on how to write cloud applications using Service Weaver.
talks.references:
# Steps of the talk

We will talk about our own experience developing cloud applications, and also key findings based on conversations with various infrastructure teams at Google. 

The way people write cloud applications today is very cumbersome, hence it slowdowns innovation and hinders applications‚Äô performance. We argue that the key reason for this is the way people organize their application code around different binaries and run them independently as microservices. Instead, we believe that (1) people should just focus on the application business logic, and split the code at logical boundaries based on the business logic; and (2) let the runtime deal with the execution challenges (e.g., how to split into microservices, how to connect them, resource management, etc.). 

We will walk through our framework that uses a custom transport protocol, and custom serialization, through our Go code generator, and how easy is to run/test/manage/debug the applications both locally and in the cloud. We will also talk on how we leverage open source projects like Kubernetes, Prometheus, Perfetto, Jaeger and Open Telemetry to deploy and instrument applications.

# Workshop pre-requisites

This submission is for a talk, but we will be happy to do a workshop as well. For the workshop, we can develop with the audience an emoji search engine integrated with ChatGPT.

Prerequisites: Go 1.20 or higher installed on your laptop.

# Github repo:
https://github.com/ServiceWeaver/

talks.title: It's a (testing) trap! - Common end-to-end pitfalls and how to solve them
talks.abstract:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a trap‚Äù - a call or feeling we all might be familiar with, not only when it comes to Star Wars. It signalizes a sudden moment of noticing imminent danger. This situation is an excellent allegory for an unpleasant realization in testing. Imagine having the best intentions regarding testing but still ending up with tests failing to deliver any value. Tests who are feeling like a pain to deal with?

When writing frontend tests, there are lots of pitfalls on the way. In sum, they can lead to lousy maintainability, slow execution time, and - in the worst-case - tests you cannot trust. But it doesn‚Äôt have to be that way. In this session, I will talk about developers‚Äô common mistakes (including mine) in tests using Jest and Cypress, at least from my experience. And, of course, how to avoid them using best practices. Testing doesn‚Äôt need to be painful, after all.
talks.comments: Thanks a lot for this opportunity! ‚ù§Ô∏è

speakers.bio:
Building software has always been a passion of mine. This is still true after almost 15 years of experience in various environments and business sectors. I've never really considered it work but "problems to solve". Yes, I love puzzles or anything that requires you to turn your head around. Passion also means curiosity and hunger for knowledge. I regularly read blogs, articles, and books and practice katas by myself. Continuous improvement is a mindset I consider essential.

If I had to pick one priority when building a product, I would choose quality. This has always been what I put first. I'm not satisfied when "It Works", it must also be done well. I always tried to improve the team I joined wherever I've been. Whether by providing experience, a fresh eye, ideas, or mentoring younger peers. About mentoring, sharing knowledge represents a key aspect of my participation in a team. I do believe that knowledge is useless if you keep it to yourself. We need to use our knowledge to teach and inspire others, the same way others have inspired us.

Putting this all together, it‚Äôs quite clear I advocate Software Craftsmanship. Hearing about this ideology for the first time has been one of the biggest milestones in my career. It is the perfect match for what I consider important in terms of mindset. Since then, I‚Äôve continuously tried to spread the ideology by sharing ideas and methodologies.

Accompagnatrice agile, co-cr√©atrice de TADx, j'ai parcouru des kilom√®tres de lignes de d√©veloppements, d'analyses fonctionnelles et d'architectures orient√©es donn√©es avant de revenir √† mes premi√®res amours : le travail d'√©quipe, dans un cadre motivant et bienveillant, autour de produits utiles et vivants.

speakers.bio: Passionate about programming computers for over 25 years, Jose made his debut in assembler and C, C for SIMD parallel machines before adopting Java as an object-oriented language. PhD in applied maths and computer science, assistant professor at the University Sorbonne Paris Nord for 25 years, and now Java Developer Advocate at Oracle. Java Champion Alumni, JavaOne Rockstar, Jose also has a passion for education and knowledge transfer. He gives talks in major international Java conferences (JavaOne, Oracle CodeOne, Devoxx in Antwerp, Paris and London, DevNexus).  He wrote numerous technical articles on Java technologies for Java Magazine, Oracle Technolgy Network. After graduating from university as a data scientist, I joined a team of mobile and web security experts. My mission is to bind data and security in order to improve the user experience.

speakers.bio:
If you ask me why I got into IT, I'd say it was a natural path for me.

As a kid, I discovered it as a hobby. I wanted to be like these cool hackers in movies. I still remember my very first programming language: `QBasic`.  The internet is like a massive free university. I had so much fun learning `C`, `C++`, and `PHP`and working on tons of fun hobby projects at that time!

Naturally, I've been through a computer engineering degree at UTC, Compi√®gne, France. It was tough but enlightening. I had skills in different domains and this degree brought all the pieces together.

My first job as a software engineer at Bloomberg LP, London, was very challenging but it felt weird at the same time. The company, the people and the projects were awesome but I couldn't get used to professional software development. It was too different to what I used to like as a hobby. Maybe this job was not for me.

In 2018, cloud computing was trending and I had no experience with it. I joined D2SI (now Devoteam Revolve) as a junior cloud computing consultant where I worked on many different and challenging projects. As a consultant, I was the knowledgable guy. I discovered that I love teaching!

Finally, I had the opportunity to join AWS in 2020 as a Solutions Architect. I discover the business world thanks to this position. It's an awesome role to hone my business and teaching skills.

Now here I am! I can't wait to share what I learned with you!
